column4: I formatted 800GB worth of pr0n, warez, cbtz, isos and VMs by mistake. Any suggestions as to how to recover? I tried diskinternals linux recovery and R-Linux but they couldn't find the old stuff :(
ddrescue and about fifteen others could or might work.
It has grown some, pulling up a few links now....
there are actually two dd-rescue apps are there not, that get confused with each other? I seem to remember that from ages ago.
correct: http://www.debianadmin.com/recover-data-from-a-dead-hard-drive-using-ddrescue.html
You could dban it and then dd_rescue to salvage it.
the hard drive is alive and kicking but the ext3 partition has been reformatted and 2% overwritten mistakenly
I think dd_rescue would or should work. did you see the link?
no I'm going to check the link out in a bit. So you are saying it doesnt just do raw disk image dumps but also gets involved in heuristics?
It will recover and repair many ext2, and now maybe ext3, I think I would dban it just to be certain.
isn't dban a data nuking proggy?
http://www.linux.com/archive/feature/48092 and http://www.linuxforums.org/forum/linux-newbie/114334-dban.html
Yes, nuke it then start fresh and no bugs, or use the Debian Recovery Console or utilities.
hold on, you are telling me to secure erase all the data on the partition I am trying to recover data from?
No, use the recovery dd_rescue or something like  it, then I personally would nuke it and start fresh with any data saved.
but whats the point if any of secure erasing the drive?
After the data save, to be certain that all blocks and sectors are 'clean'
what do you mean by data being "clean" and why wouldn't I just zero it all out instead of this crazy multiple rewrite technique..
I mean clean as in clean data sectors so that are working and not bad blocks. If you dban it is almost like a new new drive , no spin rate delays and whatnots.
is there any advantage to dbanning a hard drive over say...just doing a dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/sda a couple of times?
It is about the same, I only went into dban because of the state of the drive data and any corruptions it may now contain, but yes, you are correct.
